content:
The Regional Presidential Selection Act of 1999 may be cited as the "Regional Presidential Selection Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Regional Presidential Selection Act of 1999, also known as the "Regional Presidential Selection Act," defines key terms related to the selection of delegates for national Presidential nominating conventions of political parties, election years, national committees, and political parties. The term "State committee" refers to the organization responsible for the day-to-day operation of a political party at the State level, as determined by the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 3. SCHEDULE. In 2004, each State is required to hold primaries according to a schedule outlined in the Act, with different regions holding primaries on specific dates from March to June. In subsequent election years after 2004, the schedule for primaries will continue to be followed. In election years after 2004, each State must hold primaries on specific dates following the previous election year's schedule. If most candidates withdraw from a primary before its scheduled date, the State can cancel the primary. Regions are defined for this purpose. Region I includes Connecticut, Delaware, District of Columbia, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont, and West Virginia. Region II comprises Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oklahoma, and South Carolina. Region III includes Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota, and Wisconsin. Region IV comprises Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, and Montana. The national committees determine the regions of territories in the United States, including Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming. SEC. 4. QUALIFICATION FOR BALLOT. The Federal Election Commission certifies names of candidates for primaries. States include certified names on primary ballots along with any additional names determined by the State committee. SEC. 5. VOTING AT NATIONAL PARTY CONVENTIONS BY STATE DELEGATES. Each State committee must establish a procedure for delegate apportionment to the national Presidential nominating convention based on either a winner-take-all system or a proportionate representation system using primary results. The State committee establishes a delegate selection process based on primary results. Candidates submit a list of proposed delegates in priority order. Delegates must vote for the winner of the State primary at the national convention. Delegates selected under the system must vote for the winner of the State primary for at least 2 ballots at the national convention, unless released by the winner. SEC. 6. OPTIONAL STATE CAUCUS TO SELECT DELEGATES. (a) A State can choose to hold a caucus instead of a primary to select delegates for a national Presidential nominating convention. 
(b) The caucus must not start earlier than the primary date required by the state. 
(c) Candidates must be certified and included in the caucus in the same way as for a primary. 
(d) Each State committee must establish a procedure for delegate apportionment at the national convention. The curr_chunk discusses the selection of delegates for national Presidential nominating conventions and the methods used by political parties. The Act applies to primary or caucus elections held in connection with general elections starting from 2004 and each election year thereafter.
